Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Functional analysis of ubiquitin-mediated pathways controlling stem cell fate and tissue regeneration
Award.AbstractNarration:
Normal cellular function relies on constant regulation of protein activity and longevity. Ubiquitin ligases are enzymes that chemically couple the small polypeptide ubiquitin to other proteins to regulate their function or mark them for destruction. Ubiquitin tagging controls a wide range of key cellular processes such as cell division and cell fate decisions during development. Consequently, certain ubiquitin ligases have been implicated in many human diseases including cancer. Most animals have a large number of ubiquitin ligases (approximately 600 in humans), however, we know very little about the biological functions or specific protein targets for the majority of these enzymes. This project investigates the role of ubiquitin ligases in stem cell-based tissue regeneration using planarian flatworms as model organisms. These animals possess a large population of pluripotent stem cells that bestow upon them the remarkable ability to regenerate all of their tissues after injury or amputation. This research will identify genes encoding ubiquitin ligases in planarians and analyze their function in tissue renewal using a combination of genetic, molecular, and microscopy approaches. These experiments will reveal ubiquitin ligase genes that are required for various aspects of regeneration. The ability to inhibit ubiquitin ligase gene function in the animal will be combined with technologies designed to identify alterations in proteins modified with ubiquitin. This work will contribute to the broad goal of understanding the biological roles of ubiquitin ligases and identifying cellular targets required for stem cell regulation, tissue regeneration or body patterning.

Dr. Zayas is an investigator and educator at San Diego State University (SDSU), a Hispanic Serving Institution. This project will develop a laboratory course that will integrate undergraduate students with the research outlined here. Special attention will be given to recruiting students underrepresented in science to enroll in the course. These students will be mentored on how to prepare for diverse scientific careers to support efforts to broaden participation in STEM fields. The educational activities of this proposal include science outreach at local K-12 schools to help spark enthusiasm for biology in the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A crucial component of development and regeneration involves cellular responses to environmental and intercellular cues. Cells ?need to know? where they are, their orientation, who is in contact with them, sense damage, and perform quality control of their components. One important regulator of cell signaling pathways involves a protein called ?ubiquitin? (because it ?ubiquitous? in the cell); ubiquitin is deposited onto cellular targets via reactions performed by enzymes referred to as E3 ubiquitin ligases. The addition of ubiquitin (ubiquitylation) is utilized to control a broad range of cellular functions, including selective destruction of unwanted proteins. In spite of their importance in cell biology, our knowledge of the function of a majority of ubiquitin ligases (approximately 600 in humans) for a majority of E3 enzymes remains poorly understood. The overall goal of this project was to examine the function of E3 ubiquitin ligase genes in stem cell-based tissue regeneration using the planarian Schmidtea mediterranea. Planarians are endowed with a large population of adult stem cells (called neoblasts) that serve to replace cells lost after injury or during normal cell turnover. These animals are suitable for large RNAi screens to identify genes required for regenerative processes.

 As a first step to study the role of ubiquitin ligase genes in planarians, we sought to identify the cell- and tissue-types in which ubiquitin system genes are expressed by cloning more than 200 E3 ligase genes (out of 300 putative E3 ubiquitin ligase genes encoded in the S. mediterranea genome) and mapping their pattern of expression in the intact and regenerating planarians. Combined with an explosion in single-cell RNA-seq data, we identified a subset of E3 genes highly expressed in stem cells or their immediate progeny. We used dsRNA-mediated genetic interference (RNAi) to screen the subset of E3 ligases necessary for roles in stem cell regulation. Results from these studies revealed dozens of genes required for stem cell maintenance, cell differentiation, and tissue patterning during tissue regeneration (reviewed in Strand NS, Allen JM, Zayas RM. Post-translational regulation of planarian regeneration. Semin. Cell Dev. Biol. 2019). For example, we found that a homolog of human TRIP12 is necessary for stem cell regulation and establishing cell positional information during regeneration (Henderson et al. 2015. Dev Biol. 404), and we are currently investigating the role of a human RNF2 homolog (a component of a complex involved in ubiquitylating histone proteins to regulate gene expression) in stem cell differentiation. The work funded buy this grant formed the basis for ongoing studies aimed at identifying target substrates of ubiquitin ligases that impact regenerative processes.

Broader Impacts: A major goal of this project was to engage San Diego State University students in stem cell and regeneration research. This award supported training and research activities for four postdoctoral fellows, eight graduate students, and ten undergraduate students, including members of underrepresented groups in science. In addition, we developed a laboratory course that integrated undergraduate students with the research in my laboratory called Functional Genomics Laboratory. Over three years, this course involved 57 undergraduates in authentic research projects related to this grant: performing gene searches, cloning, wholemount in situ hybridization, and knocking down genes using RNAi (Ochoa et al. A modular laboratory course using planarians to study genes involved in tissue regeneration. Biochem. Mol. Biol. Educ. 2019). Students enrolled in this course were mentored on how to prepare for diverse scientific careers to support efforts to broaden participation in STEM fields. The new course enabled us to increase undergraduate student participation in guided primary research and served as an additional vehicle to recruit underrepresented students into a structured laboratory research experience.
